div.p: COMMON AND INFERIOR to what is EXCELLENT.
1. The current general word for "ordinary" is fán 凡 (ant. qí 奇 "remarkable").
2. Zhōng 中 (ant. yōu 優 "excellent") refers specifically to mediocrity.
3. Yōng 庸 (ant. tè 特 "of special distinction") refers to what is regularly met and not unexpected, and the word focusses on that this does not distinguish itself through any positive features.
4. Sǎn 散 (ant. jīng 精 "exquisite") refers to what can make no claim for special attention.
5. Shù 庶 (ant. zhēn 珍 "extraordinarily precious") refers to kinds of persons that there are very many of.
6. Cū 粗 (ant. jīng 精 "exquisitely civilised") refers to ordinariness as absence of cultural polish.
7. Xì 細 (ant. kuí 魁 "great, towering") refers to ordinariness as absence of real power or significance.
8. Wēi 微 (ant. jù 巨 "great") refers to relative slightness or insignificance without negative overtones.
中人 refers to a person of ordinary status or appearance.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

bibl.title: A Dictionary of Selected Synonyms in the Principal Indo-European Languages
Anthologia sive Florilegium rerum et materiarum selectarum

entry.def: Zhōng 中 (ant. yōu 優 "excellent") refers specifically to mediocrity.

sense.def: a person who is only mediocre

entry.def: The current general word for "ordinary" is fán 凡 (ant. qí 奇 "remarkable").

sense.def: what is ordinary > the profane, the secular
ordinary, unembellished; standard; customary; run of the mill; undistinguished

entry.def: Shù 庶 (ant. zhēn 珍 "extraordinarily precious") refers to kinds of persons that there are very many of.
Yōng 庸 (ant. tè 特 "of special distinction") refers to what is regularly met and not unexpected, and the word focusses on that this does not distinguish itself through any positive features.

sense.def: those who are mediocre > the mediocre, the average people

entry.def: Wēi 微 (ant. jù 巨 "great") refers to relative slightness or insignificance without negative overtones.
Sǎn 散 (ant. jīng 精 "exquisite") refers to what can make no claim for special attention.

sense.def: ordinary, of no special distinction whatsoever, run-of-the-mill
run of the mill, middling; less than extraordinary
like an oridinary stone > ordinary, mediocre, regular

entry.def: Cū 粗 (ant. jīng 精 "exquisitely civilised") refers to ordinariness as absence of cultural polish.
Cū 粗 (ant. jīng 精 "exquisitely civilised") refers to ordinariness as absence of cultural polish.
Xì 細 (ant. kuí 魁 "great, towering") refers to ordinariness as absence of real power or significance.

sense.def: slight, of no moral or intellectual significance; trifling, petty

bibl.title: 簡明古漢語同義詞詞典
簡明古漢語同義詞詞典
簡明古漢語同義詞詞典

sense.def: ordinary vulgar men of some education
of ordinary excellence, of middle excellence, medium majestic
common person; commoner; ordinary person (as opposed to the saint)
probably only used like this to fill in four-character phrases: ordinary (person)

entry.def: Pǐ fū 匹夫 (ant. jūn zǐ 君子 "gentleman; freeman") and the rarer xì rén 細人 is a purely sociological term referring to a person without public office.

sense.def: yeoman; ordinary person (who cannot by law have secondary wives and lives only with his pǐfù 匹婦 'ordinary wife')
of ordinary social status; characteristic of a person of low social status
like an ordinary man; appropriate to an ordinary man

bibl.title: 唐五代語言詞典 Táng Wǔdài yǔyán cídiǎn A Dictionary of the Language of the Tang and Five Dynasties Periods

sense.def: Tang colloquial: ordinarily, regularly, usually, as a habit, just, by all means (BIANWEN, Tang poetry)

entry.def: Xiǎo rén 小人 (ant. jūn zǐ 君子) is a term of moral or personal appraisal and refers to a person of minor worth or of no moral merit.

sense.def: person of low social status or moral quality, petty man
person of ordinary low status, close to 庶人
belong the the lower classes; be of ordinary calibre 小人哉！
be just an ordinary person; be morally petty
the concept of a petty person
morally inferior person (not necessarily of low status): petty man
used daily > ordinary, common, regular (JINGDECHUANDENGLU: 日用事 'everyday matter, regular matter, ordinary activity') This word is of rather late origina
ordinarily, in the daily activities, commonly
the ordinary people, the (ignorant) masses; the ordinary people around
the hoi polloi; intellectually ordinary people (who may be of considerable social status); a vulgar uneducated person (not necessarily plural!)
be just an unremarkable ordinary person
the concept of an ordinary person

entry.def: Pǐ fū 匹夫 (ant. jūn zǐ 君子 "gentleman; freeman") and the rarer xì rén 細人 is a purely sociological term referring to a person without public office.

sense.def: be petty fellows, be a petty man; American: be pecayune
the hoi polloi, ordinary people of some kind
be ordinary, be of ordinary talent and worth
be ordinary, be of ordinary talent and worth
the ordinary ones, those of less talent
(only) one of the set of N
